marketNews.title: Government Plans to Amend Minerba Royalty Rates
marketNews.content:
The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (ESDM) held a public consultation on Saturday, 8 March, regarding the draft amendment to the mineral and coal (minerba) royalty regulations. In the draft, the government will increase royalty rates for several mineral commodities such as nickel, copper and gold. For coal, the government plans to adjust the royalty and non‑tax state revenue (PNBP) as follows:

- IUP contracts: royalty rate rises by 1 percentage point for coal with calorific value ≤4,200 kcal/kg and >4,200‑5,200 kcal/kg when the Coal Reference Price (HBA) is ≥ US$90 per ton, becoming 9% and 11.5% respectively.
- PKP2B contracts: royalty rate rises by 1 percentage point for the same calorific ranges when HBA ≥ US$90/ton, becoming 9% and 11.5%. In addition, the Mining Revenue (PHT) for the same calorific ranges falls by 1 percentage point, becoming 4.5% and 2%.
- IUPK contracts (extension of PKP2B): the royalty range is changed. The government also plans to adjust the corporate income tax (PPh) for companies with IUPK contracts from 22% to the rate applicable under income tax regulations.

Key Takeaway: If enacted, the proposal could pressure the performance of coal producers operating under IUP licences such as Bukit Asam (PTBA) and PKP2B operators such as Indo Tambangraya Megah (ITMG). The increase in metal royalties could also pressure mineral producers such as Vale Indonesia (INCO), Trimegah Bangun Persada (NCKL), Aneka Tambang (ANTM), Bumi Resources Minerals (BRMS) and Amman Mineral Internasional (AMMN).

According to the adjustment plan, the commodities that will see the highest royalty increase are copper concentrate and ferronickel. With the copper reference price at US$9,362 per ton in March 2025, copper concentrate royalty could rise three‑fold from 5% to 15%, while ferronickel royalty could rise +150% from 2% to 5%.

For coal producers with IUPK contracts, the adjustment of the PNBP range could improve the performance of related issuers, given the HBA in March 2025 of US$128 per ton. Coal producers operating with IUPK contracts are Bumi Resources (BUMI), Indika Energy (INDY) and Adaro Andalan Indonesia (AADI).

marketNews.title: RAJA: Target Akuisisi 2 Perusahaan Rampung pada 1H25
marketNews.content:
Director General Rukun Raharja Djauhar Maulidi said on Friday, 7 March that the company is reviewing the acquisition of two companies, both targeted to be completed in the first half of 2025. He did not disclose the identities of the companies or the cost of the acquisition, but said the two target firms operate in gas distribution and LNG infrastructure, representing a move to develop the mid‑stream and downstream business.

Chandra Asri Pacific (TPIA) controlling shareholder Prajogo Pangestu sold 23.2 million TPIA shares at an average price of IDR 7,207 per share between 3–7 March 2025, totaling about IDR 167 billion to increase free float. After the transaction, Prajogo’s direct ownership fell from 5.06% to 5.03%.

Remala Abadi’s controlling shareholder and President Director Verah Wahyudi S. Wong net‑sold 20.9 million DATA shares at an average price of IDR 1,890 per share on 5 March 2025, totaling about IDR 39.5 billion. After the transaction, her ownership fell from 83.57% to 82.08%.

Hillcon Equity Management, the controlling shareholder of Hillcon (HILL), sold roughly 66 million HILL shares at IDR 2,500 per share on 4 March 2025, amounting to about IDR 165 billion. After the transaction, its stake fell from 61.76% to 59.52%.

DRMA’s commissioner Noel Aelyo Laras Kusuma Negara bought 7 million DRMA shares at IDR 670 per share on 5 March 2025, a transaction worth about IDR 4.7 billion. After the purchase, his ownership rose from 1.419% to 1.566%.

PT Sentosa Bersama Mitra plans a voluntary tender offer for 5.65 billion (50%) shares of Minna Padi Investama Sekuritas between 16 April and 15 May 2025. The offer price of IDR 13 per share is 66% lower than the PADI price of IDR 39 on 10 March, giving a maximum transaction value of IDR 73.5 billion. PT Sentosa Bersama Mitra previously bought 650 million PADI shares at an average price of IDR 15 per share on 19 February 2025, raising its stake from zero to 5.75%.

President Prabowo Subianto on Monday, 10 March ordered ride‑hailing firms, including GoTo Gojek Tokopedia (GOTO) and Grab Holdings Ltd. (Nasdaq: GRAB), to provide cash holiday bonuses (THR) to online‑motorcycle‑driver partners. The cash amount will be calculated based on work activity, with details to be discussed between the firms and the Ministry of Manpower. Prabowo said Indonesia has about 250,000 online‑motorcycle drivers and couriers. GOTO said it will give cash THR to qualifying driver partners, while Grab will calculate it based on order completion, fulfillment ratio, online hours and driver rating.

marketNews.title: Indonesian motorcycle sales February 2025
marketNews.content: The Indonesian Motor Industry Association (AISI) reported that domestic motorcycle sales reached 581,277 units in February 2025, up 4% year‑on‑year and 3.7% month‑on‑month, marking the first annual growth since October 2024. The 2‑month cumulative sales reached about 1.1 million units (‑0.8% YoY), representing 17‑17.8% of the 2025 target of 6.4‑6.7 million units set by AISI.

marketNews.title: Malaysia CPO stocks and production decline February 2025
marketNews.content: The Malaysian Palm Oil Board reported that Malaysia’s crude palm oil (CPO) stocks fell 4.31% month‑on‑month to 1.51 million tonnes in February 2025, the lowest level in five months and the lowest since April 2023. Malaysian CPO production also fell 4.16% month‑on‑month to 1.19 million tonnes, the lowest in three years due to flood‑related disruptions. Exports dropped 16.27% month‑on‑month to 1 million tonnes, the lowest in four years.

marketNews.title: China announces retaliatory tariffs on Canadian agricultural products
marketNews.content: China announced retaliatory import tariffs on Canadian agricultural and food products effective 20 March 2025. The measures impose a 100% tariff on rapeseed oil, oil cakes and peas, and a 25% tariff on aquaculture products and pork, in response to Canada’s tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles, steel and aluminium imposed in October 2024.

marketNews.title: KPK reports reduction in free‑lunch budget
marketNews.content: The Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK) said on Friday, 7 March that it received a report of a reduction in the free‑lunch budget from the standard IDR 10,000 per meal to IDR 8,000 per meal. National Nutrition Agency head Dadan Hindayana explained that the budget varies by age, with pre‑school to third‑grade primary children in most western Indonesian regions budgeted at IDR 8,000 per meal.

marketNews.title: China CPI deflation February 2025
marketNews.content: China’s consumer price index (CPI) recorded a 0.7% year‑on‑year deflation in February 2025 (versus a 0.5% year‑on‑year increase in January 2025), missing the consensus forecast of a 0.5% year‑on‑year decline. Monthly, the CPI fell 0.2% month‑on‑month versus a 0.7% increase in January, also worse than the 0.1% consensus, marking the first monthly decline since November 2024. Core CPI fell 0.1% year‑on‑year in February 2025 (versus a 0.6% increase in January).

marketNews.title: China central bank gold reserves rise February 2025
marketNews.content: China’s central bank increased its gold reserves by 16,000 fine troy ounces to a total of 73.61 million fine troy ounces at the end of February 2025, marking the fourth consecutive month of gold purchases. The reserves were valued at US$208.64 billion, up 1.02% month‑on‑month.

marketNews.title: U.S. non‑farm payrolls February 2025
marketNews.content: The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics reported that non‑farm payrolls increased by 151,000 jobs in February 2025 (versus 125,000 in January), below the consensus expectation of 160,000. The unemployment rate rose to 4.1% in February 2025 (versus 4.0% in January), slightly above the 4% consensus.
